and meet

ust wish we had
the tool

uld see how they are

f Clune

> > From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> > Reply-To: "neat=
@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Date: Sat, 30 Aug 2008 20:58:0=
4 -0000
> > To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Subject: =
[neat] Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
> > 
> > Jeff, =
that's a good thought experiment for testing my claim.  There
> > are many =
considerations, and although I may not hit all of them, I
> > think in gene=
ral it can be refuted:
> > 
> > Generally, I think HyperNEAT (i.e. NEAT wit=
h CPPNs) already
> > approximately follow the scenario that you outline:  I=
t discovers key
> > motifs (whether they be skin or something else) early i=
n evolution and
> > then as the overall body plan is deformed, the original=
 motifs are
> > often preserved (which again includes skin).  The main idea=
 is that
> > skin is like a kind of surrounding motif for the overall shape=
, and if
> > the pverall shape is warped through some kind of mutation in t=
he
> > internal CPPN, then however the shape is surrounded will naturally
>=
 > warp in the same way.
> > 
> > In fact, you can see this happen consiste=
ntly in Picbreeder.  It is
> > possible to consider the simple black outlin=
e of many of the color
> > figures as a "skin."  You can notice that it is =
special by noting that
> > often the outer band is black but everything str=
ucture inside is
> > color.  Then, if the shape of the overall image warps,=
 so does the
> > outer membrane.
> > 
> > However, you might say that such =
a "skin" is not complex enough to be
> > convincing.  Perhaps skin should h=
ave multiple parts, i.e. its own
> > special structure.  In fact, if you lo=
ok closely, you can find many
> > such examples.  For example, there are of=
ten double-layer outer
> > membranes that form, such as in this image:
> > =

> > http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D317
> > 
> > There i=
s a clear outer structure that surrounds the complex curvature
> > of the o=
bject.
> > 
> > Or, perhaps more interestingly, you can get several layers =
of color
> > bands, but only on the outer membrane, such as in this image t=
hat ends
> > in a light blue that becomes green, then becomes yellow, befor=
e
> > sinking into the inner-body color of orange:
> > 
> > http://picbreed=
er.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D4227
> > 
> > To show that the outer mem=
brane warps easily and naturally regardless
> > of shape changes (even comp=
lex ones), I further evolved that image to
> > get a new shape, and you can=
 see that the outer membrane has the same
> > motif nevertheless, nicely wa=
rped to accommodate the new overall
shape:
> > 
> > http://picbreeder.org/s=
earch/showgenome.php?sid=3D5635
> > 
> > It is also important to note that =
outer membranes in nature are not
> > uniform covers and often transition i=
nto something else on the
> > surface.  For example, consider lips and eyes=
.  Or perhaps even more
> > importantly, consider fingernails, where the ou=
ter cover actually
> > falls *under* something else (i.e. the nail), violat=
ing the covering
> > rule.  I point these exceptions out because in Picbree=
der you also
> > often see almost consistent outer motifs that are broken i=
n a couple
> > places.  While these locations often are arbitrary, the poin=
t is that
> > such a capability could be exploited if it actually mattered.=

> > 
> > Moving from 2-D to 3-D should not matter in the case of skin, jus=
t as
> > moving CPPNs from 2-D to 4-D continues to allow all the same
> > r=
egularities.  So when you see examples in 2-D, they are also possible
> > i=
n 3-D for the same reasons.
> > 
> > Most of these outer skin motifs can ar=
ise early when the shape is
> > simple and are then easily preserved.  Howe=
ver, they are not always
> > preserved.  For example, the multicolor skin a=
bove evolved into a
> > different multicolor skin in one lineage:
> > 
> > =
http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D4228
> > 
> > This phenom=
enon is expected from the analogy with nature, just as
> > scales can evolv=
e into fur, or fur into uncovered skin, all still
> > serving the role of o=
uter membrane.
> > 
> > I think it's important to note that skin or an oute=
r membrane is not
> > really any different from any other CPPN-generated mo=
tif, in that it
> > can be preserved, warped, or changed in its internal st=
ructure.  So I
> > don't think there is really anything special going on in=
 the argument
> > compared to the discovery of symmetry or other convention=
s.
> > 
> > ken 
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@>=
 wrote:
> >> 
> >> Hello all-
> >> 
> >> Ken has challenged us all many tim=
es to think about whether there
is any
> >> need for a process of developme=
nt. The identity of cells in
> > developmental
> >> processes is determined=
 by local contextual information whereas Ken
> >> advocates skipping that b=
y letting cells determine their identity
> > via giving
> >> them their obj=
ective coordinates. The question is whether we lose
> > anything
> >> impor=
tant to the evolution of complexity by skipping this step.
> >> 
> >> I thi=
nk it is a fascinating question and, unable to come up with
a good
> >> rea=
son why development matters myself, but wanting to give the
> > argument a
=
> >> rigorous evaluation, I have been asking many people in our field
wheth=
er
> >> they can describe something unique that a developmental process
> >=
 provides. No
> >> one has come up with  a reason that compels me, so I hav=
e become a
> > strong
> >> advocate of the lack of a need for an unfolding =
process.
> >> 
> >> However, in the course of watching a keynote on develop=
ment in
natural
> >> systems at this year's gecco, an argument in favor of =
development
> > occurred
> >> to me that may have merit. I am interested to=
 hear what y'all think
> > of it.
> >> 
> >> The argument is this: it might=
 be easier to evolve certain
large-scale
> >> properties when the organism =
is simple and small and then scale/grow
> > them
> >> up, rather than incor=
porating them into an already complex
phenotype. I
> >> think an example il=
lustrates the point best. Imagine evolution
> > figuring out
> >> how to pu=
t a coat of skin on an organism. It is not that hard to
> > figure out
> >>=
 what the shape of that skin should be when the embryo has only a few
> > c=
ells.
> >> Once that simple and small coat of skin has formed, it can follo=
w
> > the simple
> >> rule of keeping the layer of skin the same thickness,=
 and adding
cells
> >> within that layer to grow to cover any arbitrary sha=
pe that the
> > phenotype
> >> becomes. This simple rule could produce a sk=
in shell for a bat or a
> > jaguar.
> >> Now consider how hard it would be =
for 3D hyperneat to create a skin
> > shell
> >> for a bat or a jaguar. The=
 mathematical function to create such
> > outlines is
> >> very complex (al=
though it is less so if it is a composition of other,
> >> already created =
functions that produced the rest of the body).
Still, it
> >> seems that th=
is task might be harder for hyperneat than following
> > the simple
> >> de=
velopmental rules outlined above.
> >> 
> >> What do you think? I would hap=
pily be convinced that this argument is
> >> without merit, so please let m=
e know if you see any problems with it.
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff =
Clune
> >> 
> >> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> >> 
> >=
> jclune@
> >> 
> >
